section.title: Four Ways to Represent a Function

ul.li: Represent relations verbally, numerically, graphically or algebraically and translate between representations.
Determine if a relation is a function, and represent functions using appropriate notation.
Evaluate and graph piecewise functions (including absolute value and step functions).
Determine if a function is even, odd, or neither using multiple representations.
Graphically determine the intervals over which a function is increasing, decreasing, or constant.
Evaluate functions using numerical or algebraic input, particularly difference quotients.

subsubsection.title: Functions
subsubsection.p: A relation is a rule which links an input variable to an output; given one piece of information, we can determine the corresponding piece. A special type of relation is one called a function.
subsubsection.definition: Function/Domain/Range Function Domain Range A function f is a rule that assigns to each element x in a set D one element, called f(x), in a set E. The set D is called the domain of the function. The range of f is the set of all possible values of f(x) as x varies throughout the domain.

Independent Variable/Dependent Variable Independent Variable Dependent Variable A symbol that represents an arbitrary element in the domain is called an independent variable. A symbol representing an arbitarary element in the range of a function is called a dependent variable.

example.statement: Let C(t) represent the number of courses offered campus-wide during the week at time t, and O(t) represent the number of students walking on the South Oval at time t last Monday. Is C a function? What about O?
example.solution: C is not a function because at least one input has multiple outputs (for example, Monday at 12:00pm has multiple classes). O is a function because at time t last Monday specifically, there is a only one number of students on the South Oval.

subsubsection.title: Representations of Functions
subsubsection.introduction: In mathematics, particularly applied mathematics, we need to be able to interpret real-world phenomena in four ways: numerically, algebraically, verbally, and graphically.

example.statement:
The price of gas at a certain 7-11 in Norman was $4.37 per gallon on June 26th.
Is this information presented numerically, algebraically, verbally, or graphically?
Represent this situation in the other three ways.

A rectangular storage container has an open top, and a volume of 20 m^3. The length of its base is twice its width. Material for the base costs $5 per square meter; material for the sides costs $3 per square meter. Express the cost of materials as a function of the width of the base.

assemblage.title: Vertical Line Test
assemblage.p: A curve in the xy-plane is the graph of a function of x if and only if no vertical line intersects the curve more than once.

example.solution: The first graph is a function because it passes the vertical line test, but the second is not a function because it fails the vertical line test between [-2,2].

subsubsection.title: Piecewise Defined Functions
subsubsection.definition: A piecewise function is a function defined by different formulas in different parts of their domains.

subsubsection.title: Symmetry
subsubsection.definition:
Even/Odd Function Even Function Odd Function
A function f is said to be even if it has the property that f(-x) = f(x). A function g is said to be odd if it has the property that g(-x)=-g(x)

example.statement:
Determine if the following functions are even, odd, or neither.
f(x) = x^7 + x^5 - x
g(x) = 3-x^2
h(x) = x^2 - x^3

subsubsection.title: Increasing and Decreasing Functions
subsubsection.definition:
Increasing/Decreasing Increasing Decreasing
Let f be a function defined on some input interval. f is said to be
increasing if the output values increase on the interval
decreasing if the output values decrease on the interval

example.solution: The function is increasing on (-\infty,-1)\cup (2,\infty) and decreasing on (-1,2)

example.statement: If the point (3,5) is on the graph of an even function, what other point must also be on the graph? What about if the function is odd? Justify your answers.
example.solution: The point (-3,5) is on the even function, and the point (-3,-5) is on the odd function.
